question:
Here is a complete sentence of only two words:
Birds fly.
We know what this sentence is about. It is not about dogs or horses. It is about...

Birds...
Birds fly is a sentence, but the word birds by itself is not a...

The word birds by itself merely names a topic that we might talk about.
To make a sentence of it, we must tell something about...

Birds fly.
In this sentence, the word that tells something about birds is...

Birds fly.
This sentence doesn't state that birds eat, sleep, or sing. It tells that birds...

To tell about something means to make a statement about it.
Birds fly.
The word fly makes a statement about...
A group of words that both names something and makes a .... about it is a complete sentence.

Birds fly.
This little sentence is like most sentences because it has ... parts: a naming part and a telling part.

Flowers fade.
In this sentence .... is the naming part, and .... is the telling part.

Glass breaks.
In this sentence .... is the naming part, and .... is the telling part.

Water freezes.
In this sentence, water is the .... part, and freezes is the .... part
A complete sentence usually has how many parts?

We often use the word subject to mean topic; for example,
'What subjects (topics) did you discuss?'
In grammar, we call the naming part of a sentence the subject because it names the topic that the sentence is about.
Water freezes
Water is the ... of this sentence.

In grammar, we call the telling part of a sentence the predicate.
Water freezes
The predicate of this sentence is ... .

Predicate is a long word. Let's break it up into three syllables and learn to spell it:
pre-di-cate
The third syllable of predicate is ... .

Iron bends.
In this sentence, the subject is ...., and the predicate is .....

Milk sours.
In this sentence, milk is the ...., and sours is the .....

A sentence usually has two parts.
The grammar names for these two parts are subject and ... .
The predicate makes a statement about the ....

Wrote.	Talked.	Melted.
Each of these words could be the .... of a sentence.

Bread.	Pencil	Engine
Each of these words could be the .... of a sentence.

Arrives.	Henry
Which word could be used as the subject of a sentence?

Elephants.	returned
Which word could be used as the predicate of a sentence?

Answered..	vegetables.	stumbled
Which word could be used as a subject?

Kitchen.	money.	boiled
Which word could be used as a predicated?

Birds fly.	Water freezes.	Iron bends.	Milk sours.
In the above sentences, the subject comes .... the predicate.

In most English sentences, we usually first name what we are talking about; then we make a statement about what we have named.
Most English sentences begin with the ...

In analyzing the following sentences, the subject is written in bold, and the predicate is underlined.
Examples:.	Grass grows.	Dogs bark.	Ice melts.

Identify the subject .... and predicate .... in this sentence.
Mosquitoes bite.

Although all are printed as sentence, only one of the following pairs of words really is a sentence. Select the word pair that is really a sentence.
Cold water.	Before noon.	Snow falls.	Broken wheel.

Only one of the following pairs of words is a sentence.
Select the word pair that is really a sentence
Barking dog.	Almost five.	Falling rain.	Gas explodes.
